name: Allantoin
benefits: Moisturizes, soothes itchiness, and heals injured skin.
target: In general, those with dry, itchy skin looking for better skin texture and smoothness, regardless of skin type, age, or conditions.
frequency: Can be used day in and day out without general side effects of any kind, according to Shamban.
compatible: Herrmann says when used in scar creams, allantoin is often combined with ingredients like silicone and other emollients to amplify results.
incompatible: Herrmann adds that combining it with other exfoliants could produce an exaggerated reaction, causing excess irritation, if strengths are too high.

name: Aloe Vera
benefits: Calms, soothes, and hydrates the skin
target: In general, anyone looking to soothe burns, including sunburn and windburn, and moisturize their skin.
frequency: Nussbaum recommends applying it two to three times daily.
compatible: To increase the calming benefits, Nussbaum suggests using it with anti-inflammatory ingredients.
incompatible: Nussbaum says to avoid using aloe vera products that also contain alcohol, which will negate the moisturizing, soothing effects of the aloe, and also avoid combining it with chemical exfoliants, which could worsen any stinging or irritation. If you have a burn, Nussbaum advises against using it with an ointment or petrolatum, which will trap the heat inside.

name: Alpha Hydroxy Acids
benefits: Exfoliate the top layers of skin to minimize dullness and even out texture; some AHAs can also stimulate collagen production, while others have antioxidant and hydrating properties.
target: Given their wide range of effects, most people can benefit from using AHAs, says Nazarian, so long as you find the right alpha hydroxy acid and concentration of it for your particular skin type.
frequency: This differs greatly based on the particular acid, product, and your skin. Follow product directions, but always start slow, using any AHA only once or twice per week and gradually increasing frequency as your skin can tolerate it, suggests Nussbaum.
compatible: Peptides can slow the penetration of AHAs, making them less irritating, says Nussbaum. You can also pair them with hydrating ingredients.
incompatible: Avoid using retinoids at the same time of day as AHAs, and be cautious when using both BHAs (beta hydroxy acids, such as salicylic acid) and AHAs in order to minimize irritation.

name: Amino Acids
benefits: Soothe skin, help moisturize, act as antioxidants
target: In general, whatever amino acids are added to your skincare will be catered to the function of the product.
frequency: How often can you use it? You can use amino acids as often as you want; they are gentle enough for everyday use.
compatible: Pretty much everything; glycerides, ceramides, and peptides in particular.
incompatible: Amino acids can be mixed with a host of other ingredients.

name: Amoxicillin
benefits: Most commonly used to treat upper respiratory bacterial infections and urinary tract infections; sometimes used as a second-line treatment for acne.
target: Those dealing with moderate to severe inflammatory acne, and who can't take the tetracycline class of antibiotics (monocycline, doxycycline) because of allergy or pregnancy.
frequency: It's usually prescribed twice daily for acne, though as with any antibiotics for acne, it should be discontinued after three to four months of use.
compatible: Oral antibiotics are generally paired with topical medications that contain benzoyl peroxide and topical retinoids, says Zeichner.
incompatible: Other topical antibiotics, which can increase the likelihood of developing bacterial resistance.

name: Apple Cider Vinegar
benefits: Balances pH, chemically exfoliates, and antibacterial.
target: In general, people with oily and acneic skin.
frequency: The use of apple cider vinegar depends on what product and concentration you're using it in.
compatible: Anti-inflammatories.
incompatible: Other acids, retinoids.

name: Arbutin
benefits: Lightens dark spots, lessens appearance of acne scars, helps even out skin tone.
target: Arbutin is generally safe for all skin types.
frequency: Arbutin can be used twice a day. It is safe to apply on clean skin with other creams and serums. It can also be used in the summer since it does not make skin more sensitive to the sun.
compatible: Vitamin C, AHAs
incompatible: While there are no known negative interactions with other skincare ingredients, heat can degrade the effectiveness of arbutin.﻿﻿

name: Argireline
benefits: Prevents the muscle movement that leads to wrinkle formation. Argireline also promotes collagen production and optimizes the function of collagen, which both fight fine lines and improve moisture levels in the skin, says Shah.
target: Anyone looking to smooth out wrinkles caused by repeated muscle movement in areas such as the forehead and around the eyes. It’s also a good pick for anyone with dry skin as it actually helps allocate moisture to the area of application.
frequency: It can be used daily.
compatible: One study suggests that it works well in conjunction with another peptide, tripeptide-10-cirtrulline, which increases the permeability for argireline to penetrate to a depth where it can target muscles that cause wrinkles, says Linkner. It’s also often combined with hyaluronic acid to up the hydration benefits.
incompatible: Generally speaking, argireline works well with all ingredients.

name: Ascorbyl Glucoside
benefits: Neutralizes skin-damaging free radicals, inhibits the production of pigment to fade and prevent dark spots, boosts collagen production.
target: In general, because this is a less potent version of vitamin C, it's a good option for all skin types and anyone looking to brighten a dull complexion, enhance radiance, and stave off signs of aging such as fine lines and wrinkles, advises Nussbaum.
frequency: Recommended use is usually once a day, though it can be used twice daily as well.
compatible: As an antioxidant, ascorbyl glucoside plays nice with many different ingredients, though it works especially well with niacinamide, a type of vitamin B. "When combined, these two ingredients can help address issues such as loss of firmness and elasticity, wrinkles and fine lines, unevenness in the complexion, and large pores," explains Solomon. All antioxidants also work well with sunscreen, offering an added layer of protection.
incompatible: Benzoyl peroxide can oxidize vitamin C and should therefore be avoided. Vitamin C and retinol are active at different pHs and therefore should be used separately if you want the full potential of each ingredient, notes Nussbaum.

name: Avocado Oil
benefits: Helps the skin maintain hydration and minimizes damage from free radicals.
target: Because of its anti-inflammatory properties, Russak recommends avocado oil for anybody who has eczema, acne, seborrheic dermatitis, or psoriasis.
frequency: Avocado oil is safe to use daily in a dilute form. If it is included in a product’s formulation, follow the manufacturer’s instructions.
compatible: Russak recommends combining avocado oil with retinol. “The most absorption of the retinol happens with a fat-soluble content,” Russak explains. “Combining it together with an oil will increase absorption and decrease the irritation from it.” Although avocado oil has moisturizing properties, Hayag says it also would be beneficial for maximal moisture to use it in combination with a humectant like hyaluronic acid in order to draw water into the skin.
incompatible: There are no ingredients that contraindicate with avocado oil, but Russak suggests refraining from using the oil with other oils, such as vitamin K. “You’re really just creating too much of the lipids on the surface of the skin, and lipids start competing in terms of how they penetrate into the skin, so it will decrease the efficacy of whatever you’re trying to do,” Russak explains.

name: Azelaic Acid
benefits: Fights acne, treats rosacea, lightens pigmentation, and removes dead skin cells.
target: In general, anyone with acne-prone, rosacea-prone skin and hyperpigmentation. Dr. Fusco says azelaic acid is recommended for all skin types and is even safe for those who are pregnant.
frequency: It is safe to use twice a day (morning and night) or once every other day for those with sensitive skin.
compatible: Alpha-hydroxy acids (AHA), beta-hydroxy acid (BHA), and retinol.
incompatible: Azelaic acid is safe to use in conjunction with most, if not all, ingredients.﻿﻿

name: Bakuchiol
benefits: Wrinkle reduction, increases skin firmness, and reduces the appearance of pores.
target: Generally, bakuchiol is safe for all skin types.
frequency: It's safe to use twice a day, in the morning before moisturizer and at night before any serums.
compatible: Other hydrating ingredients, like squalane and PHAs.
incompatible: Glycolic acid could degrade the formulation.

name: Benzoyl Peroxide
benefits: Reduces acne-causing bacteria
target: In general, benzoyl peroxide is suitable for those looking to treat mild to moderate acne at home.
frequency: Benzoyl peroxide shouldn't be used more than twice per day, at most.
compatible: Benzoyl peroxide works well in combination with salicyclic acid to treat acne.
incompatible: Don't use multiple benzoyl peroxide products at once. Benzoyl peroxide may also reduce the efficacy of vitamin C products when used as part of the same routine.

name: Benzyl Alcohol
benefits: Preserves, stabilizes, and dissolves ingredients
target: In general, benzyl alcohol is safe to use by anyone who does not have a true contact allergy to it. Krant adds that those who prefer un-preserved products would want to avoid products containing standard preservatives like benzyl alcohol, though it may risk contamination.
frequency: Benzyl alcohol is safe to use on a daily basis if you're not sensitive to it and if it's used at a low concentration.
compatible: Benzyl alcohol works well with most, if not all, other ingredients.
incompatible: Benzyl alcohol works well with most, if not all, other ingredients.

name: Beta Glucan
benefits: Boosts skin barrier, smooths skin, antioxidant
target: In general, people with compromised skin barriers, but anyone can use them.
frequency: You can use it as often as you would like.
compatible: Retinols, or anything else dehydrating or irritating. Sunscreens, as it helps reduce issues related to UV exposure.

name: Biotin
benefits: Contributes to overall skin health
target: According to Jaliman, anyone deficient in biotin can take the supplement.
frequency: Garshick says the general dose of a biotin supplement used is 2.5 to 3 mg (2500 to 3000 mcg) a day, but it hasn't been extensively studied, so it is still unknown what the best optimal dosing is. However, Jaliman says a supplement is safe for daily use for most but advises people to follow the directions on the specific product they purchase. Because it depends on the micrograms, Jaliman suggests checking the label to decide how often it should be taken.
compatible: Jaliman recommends combining biotin with protein supplements. "Protein helps the body to produce keratin, which is vital to the hair structure and also skin and nails," Jaliman explains. She also recommends taking collagen in conjunction with a biotin supplement. "Collagen is found in the layer of the skin that gives the skin its fullness and plumpness," she adds.
incompatible: Garshick says some antibiotics and anti-seizure medications can affect the absorption of biotin, so it is always best to discuss with your doctor prior to starting a biotin supplement (or any supplement, in general).

name: Butylene Glycol
benefits: Retains moisture, dissolves ingredients, and improves application.
target: In general, anyone looking for a way to effectively moisturize their skin.
frequency: Butylene glycol is safe for daily use for those who do not have an allergy to it or very sensitive skin.
compatible: As a solvent, butylene glycol works well with ingredients that are not water-soluble and are difficult to dissolve.
incompatible: Butylene glycol works well with most, if not all, ingredients.

name: Caffeine
benefits: Reduces wrinkles, brightens skin, gets rid of inflammation.
target: In general, people with concerns about wrinkles or aging.
frequency: Usually, it's used once a day, in the mornings.
compatible: Vitamin C and ginseng for an ultra-brightening effect.
incompatible: N/A

name: Caprylyl Glycol
benefits: Attracts water to and holds it in the skin, but also has preservative-like properties that can help prevent other ingredients from spoiling and extend the shelf life of the product, says Palep. It also helps products spread and absorb more easily into skin, says Belkin.
target: Generally speaking, it works well for all skin types, especially those looking to keep their skin smooth and moisturized.
frequency: This is largely dependent on the product within your regimen that contains capryl glycol in the formula, says Solomon. Generally speaking, moisturizers and lotions can be used throughout the day, but in case there's another active ingredient in there that may cause irritation with multiple uses, the safest thing is to follow particular product instructions.
compatible: It is often used with other ingredients known to hydrate the skin, such as honey, aloe, and hyaluronic acid, says Solomon.
incompatible: As a rule, it can be used with most other ingredients.

name: Carrot
benefits: Increases cell turnover, brightens skin, reduces inflammation.
target: In general, anyone concerned about their skin becoming dull. However, people with sensitive skin may want to avoid it.
frequency: You can use it in the AM and PM, but no more than twice a day.
compatible: Hydrators like hyaluronic acid, non-retinol exfoliants, Vitamin E.
incompatible: Retinols, because they're also Vitamin A.

name: Castor Oil
benefits: Hydrating, soothing, detoxifying
target: In general, people with problematic skin, or people who want to prevent wrinkles. Pregnant women should avoid Castor oil as it can induce labor.
frequency: once a week
compatible: Other oils like almond and jojoba
incompatible: Any other possible irritants.﻿﻿

name: Ceramides
benefits: Rebuild and restore the protective barrier of the skin to retain moisture, improve visible signs of aging, and block environmental damage.
target: In general, anyone with dry skin or anyone interested in anti-aging skincare.
frequency: It’s safe for frequent use and is recommended to be applied twice daily.
compatible: Cholesterol and fatty acids. “There are three big classes of lipids
incompatible: Ceramides are safe to use in conjunction with most if not all ingredients.

name: Cetearyl Alcohol
benefits: Stabilizes products, Prevents separation, and Thickens.
target: In general, anyone who doesn't have an allergy can safely use cetearyl alcohol.
frequency: Daily.
compatible: Most other emulsifiers.
incompatible: Cetearyl alcohol is safe to use with most other ingredients, but it can be comedogenic when used in conjunction with ceteareth-20, according to Fusco.

name: Charcoal
benefits: Removes toxins
target: Theoretically, charcoal can remove excess oil, so those with oily skin would benefit the most from trying a charcoal-based skincare product.
frequency: Because there are no proven benefits when used in skincare, Wong says there is no information on how often charcoal should be used on the skin. However, Levin adds that charcoal is inert and does not cause allergic reactions or irritation.
compatible: Clays, which can absorb oil from the skin.
incompatible: Because charcoal adsorbs (binds to) other substances to remove them, Wong says it's a good idea to avoid using actives with the ingredient but adds that they can be used after the charcoal has been rinsed off.

name: Cocoa Butter
benefits: Heals chapped skin, moisturizes, fights aging
target: In general, anyone who in need of a body moisturizer—however, if you easily get body acne, you might want to skip this one.
frequency: As much as you want, really.
compatible: Vitamin E oil, shea butter
incompatible: Other potentially pore-clogging ingredients

name: Collagen
benefits: Moisturizes the skin.
target: Graf says in general, anyone interested in moisturization and anti-aging can use collagen skincare.
frequency: Graf says topical collagen, as well as oral collagen, can be used on a daily basis. When applied to the skin, collagen can be used be morning or night or both as it's not sun-sensitizing.
compatible: If your ultimate goal of using collagen skincare is to stimulate collagen production, Hayag recommends adding to your routine a retinoid or retinol (which she calls the gold standard for boosting collagen) or peptides and growth factors as a less irritating option that can help by acting as “messengers” to signal cells to create collagen. Hayag also recommends vitamin C (another collagen producer) and sunscreen with UVA protection to prevent your collagen from breaking down further.
incompatible: In general, collagen is safe to use with most ingredients and topical products. "When you apply hydrolyzed collagen, it gets right into the skin and penetrates rapidly," Graf explains, and for that reason, she says it shouldn't interfere with any other product or ingredient.

name: Colloidal Oatmeal
benefits: Protect, prevent water loss, and soothe the skin.
target: In general, colloidal oatmeal can be used by anyone to hydrate and moisturize the skin, but King says it is particularly helpful for those with dry skin and conditions like eczema.
frequency: The recommended use for colloidal oatmeal is twice daily.
compatible: Colloidal oatmeal can be used in conjunction with ingredients that can be irritating to the skin, such as alpha- and beta-hydroxy acids and retinoids, to help minimize irritation and disruption of the skin barrier.
incompatible: Colloidal oatmeal works well with most, if not all, other ingredients.

benefits: Antioxidant, stimulates collagen production﻿﻿
target: In general, anyone looking to get rid of hyperpigmentation.
frequency: Twice a day.
compatible: Copper peptides don't have an enhanced performance when used simultaneously with any particular ingredient, but in general, it's recommended that they are used in conjunction with a barrier-protecting moisturizer.
incompatible: Dermatologists typically recommend that you don't use copper peptides simultaneously with vitamin C, but each case is different depending on the formulas you're using. Consult a dermatologist.

name: CoQ10
benefits: Evens skin tone, reduces sun damage, improves skin hydration.
target: Generally, CoQ10 is safe for most everyone to use. However, those with vitiligo should consult their dermatologist before use.
frequency: CoQ10 can be used during your morning and night skincare routines. Apply it before you apply any heavy moisturizers.
compatible: Aloe vera, vitamin C, vitamin B3, hyaluronic acid
incompatible: No known interactions.

name: Cyclopentasiloxane
benefits: Gives products a silky texture, seals hydration, and dissolves heavier ingredients
target: In general, anyone looking to soften their skin with a lightweight product
frequency: Cyclopentasiloxane is safe to use on a daily basis.
compatible: Robinson says it works well when combined with heavier oils or silicones because it makes them easier to spread on the skin.
incompatible: Cyclopentasiloxane works well with most, if not, all other ingredients.

name: Dimethicone
benefits: Gives a silky texture to products, seals hydration, and protects the skin.
target: It's safe for all ages and recommended for those who want to prevent dry, rough, scaly skin.
frequency: Daily.
compatible: Humectants and active ingredients that cause dryness and irritation.
incompatible: Dimethicone works well with most, if not all, other ingredients.

name: Emollients
benefits: Smoothes and softens the skin by helping to repair cracks in the skin barrier thus preventing water loss; acts as a lubricating agent in products.
target: WHO SHOULD USE IT Emollients are good for most skin types, the one exception being those with naturally very oily skin, notes Greenfield. In this case, emollients, particularly heavy, oil-rich products, can potentially be too heavy and lead to clogged pores and breakouts.
frequency: HOW OFTEN CAN YOU USE IT Barring the exception noted above about oily skin and thicker emollients, they can generally be used regularly and liberally.
compatible: ﻿WORKS WELL WITH "Emollients work well with a range of other skincare ingredients," says Nussbaum. In moisturizers, emollients work best when paired with other moisturizing agents that have occlusive or humectant properties, meaning they coat and cover the skin or attract water to it, respectively, she explains. They can also be combined with other actives, such as anti-inflammatory botanical extracts.
incompatible: DON'T USE WITH Avoid pairing emollients with ingredients that can have potentially irritating side-effects that you don't want sealed into the skin, cautions Nussbaum, who cites retinols and alpha- and beta-hydroxy acids as common examples.

name: Eucalyptus Oil
benefits: It has antimicrobial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties, though Chang says more studies are needed to confirm these skin benefits.
target: Neither Chang nor Robinson recommends eucalyptus oil for dermatologic applications.
frequency: Eucalyptus oil can be inhaled as needed to ease cold symptoms or relax the muscles, but neither dermatologist recommends the use of eucalyptus oil for dermatologic applications.
compatible: Like most essential oils, eucalyptus oil should always be diluted in a carrier solution, such as a fatty oil, before use.
incompatible: Inform your doctor of any medications you’re taking or products you’re using before trying eucalyptus oil.

name: Ferulic Acid
benefits: Decreases formation of fine lines and wrinkles, brown spots, and other signs of premature aging.
target: In general, anyone interested in an anti-aging skin regimen. Everyone can benefit from using an antioxidant to protect themselves from free-radical damage, but they can cause possible irritation, so not all antioxidants are the right concoction for each skin type.
frequency: It's safe to use every day. Apply it in the morning to clean, dry skin before your moisturizer and sunscreen.
compatible: Other antioxidants, particularly vitamins C and E and resveratrol.
incompatible: Exfoliating acids like glycolic, lactic, and salicylic acids because they can alter the pH, which then changes the effectiveness of the antioxidant.

name: GLUCONOLACTONE
benefits: Improves skin texture and tone, hydrates, offers some antioxidant benefits.
target: In general, it’s good for all skin types, particularly those with sensitive or mature skin who can’t tolerate the irritation that can come from AHAs and BHAs, notes Farber.
frequency: If you’re not using any other chemical exfoliants in your routine, it’s gentle enough for daily use. Otherwise, use it a few times per week.
compatible: Tried and true skincare staples—namely, vitamin C, retinoids, and alpha- and beta-hydroxy acids—as part of an overall anti-aging regimen.
incompatible: It plays nice with most other ingredients, although you do want to be cautious about over-exfoliation when it’s used in tandem with other acids or exfoliants such as retinoids.

name: Glycerin
benefits: Moisturizes skin, smoothes skin, makes skin appear dewy.
target: Generally, glycerin is safe for all skin types.
frequency: Products with glycerin can be used topically multiple times a day.
compatible: Other moisturizing ingredients, like rose water or hyaluronic acid.
incompatible: There are no known interactions, however glycerin should not be used in a 100% concentration.

name: Goji Berry
benefits: Promotes collagen and elastin production, reduces hyperpigmentation, reduces oxidative stress.
target: In general, anyone with uneven skin tone.
frequency: Once or twice a day.
compatible: Hydrators and barrier boosters.
incompatible: Don't ingest them if you have issues with blood thinning or diabetes.

name: Grapeseed Oil
benefits: Moisturizes, lightens dark circles, fades scars, tightens skin, prevents sun damage.
target: All skin types, including sensitive and acne-prone.
frequency: Once-daily.
compatible: Other natural oils like avocado, almond, and jojoba.
incompatible: Anything harsh or drying that could counteract the oil's emollient qualities (retinol, salicylic acid, etc.).

benefits: Soothes and protects the skin, reduces sebum, and minimizes signs of aging.
target: In general, green tea is suitable for almost all skin types unless you have a known hypersensitivity to it, according to Kim.
frequency: Green says not only is it safe to consume green tea daily, but it's also safe to use it in your daily skincare routine.
compatible: According to Kim, green tea is best used in combination with other antioxidants because they work synergistically. "Vitamin C helps to reduce degradation of EGCG, and in turn, EGCG can enhance the antioxidant effect of both Vitamins C and E," Kim explains. "There may also be enhanced skin penetration when EGCG is added to hyaluronic acid because of the latter’s strongly hydrating properties."
incompatible: According to Kim, there are no products you must avoid when using green tea topically.

name: Hemp Seed Oil
benefits: Reduces inflammation, hydrates, regulates oil production.
target: In general, people with acneic or combination skin.
frequency: As often as you would use any oil—roughly twice a day.
compatible: Acids and retinoids as it can mitigate the irritation they cause.
incompatible: Hemp seed oil can be used universally.

name: Hyaluronic Acid
benefits: Moisturizes skin, reduces appearance of wrinkles, replenishes cell moisture, speeds wound healing.
target: In general, hyaluronic acid is safe for all skin types, but it is especially helpful for those with dry skin. However, those with rosacea or eczema may want to test patch HA to make sure it doesn't irritate skin.
frequency: Hyaluronic acid can be applied twice a day topically, at morning and at night during your skincare routine, but injected hyaluronic acid and ingestible hyaluronic acid should be administered by a doctor.
compatible: Vitamin C, vitamin B5, and glycolic acid.
incompatible: There are no known negative reactions with hyaluronic acid.

name: Hydrocortisone
benefits: As a spot treatment, reduces redness and inflammation from breakouts.
target: Anyone (who isn't allergic to the ingredient) looking to target a specific inflamed breakout, rather than an area of the face.
frequency: Apply no more than twice daily for up to two weeks.
compatible: Benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, sulfur, and retinoids.
incompatible: Other hydrocortisone products or on cortisone injection sites.

name: Isopropyl Myristate
type: Emollient, though it also acts as a thickening agent and lubricant in beauty products.
benefits: Strengthens the skin's natural moisture barrier to lock in hydration, enhances the penetration of other ingredients, thickens formulas, and makes those with a high oil content feel silky rather than greasy.
target: Isopropyl myristate is ideal for anyone with normal to dry skin looking for moisturization benefits, according to Palep.
frequency: For the best results, follow the directions on the product it's found in, though daily or twice daily use is generally fine.
compatible: Isopropyl myristate works well with an assortment of active ingredients, says Solomon, which is why it's found in so many different types of products and formulas.
incompatible: Because it does enhance penetration, it’s important to assess the other ingredients in the formula and whether this increased penetration can cause unexpected side effects such as irritation, cautions Palep.

name: Jojoba Oil
type: Emollient that softens and smoothes the skin
benefits: Hydrates the skin, balances natural oil production, delivers antioxidant protection, has anti-inflammatory effects, may have some antibacterial properties, and can also help reduce acne.
target: Everyone can use jojoba oil, but it's an especially good choice for those with dry skin or those who are prone to acne or redness, says Nussbaum.
frequency: It's safe to use daily and even multiple times per day.
compatible: Jojoba oil can be combined with many other ingredients—it's a staple in many cosmetic formulations—and is often combined with other emollients, oils, and/or moisturizing ingredients such as shea butter, ceramides, beeswax, and hyaluronic acid.
incompatible: There are currently no ingredients known to have any kind of negative interaction with jojoba oil.

name: Kojic Acid
benefits: Inhibits an enzyme necessary in the production of melanin, helping to fade dark spots and discoloration. It also delivers some antioxidant protection.
target: Anyone seeking to improve the look of discoloration caused by sun damage, melasma, and/or post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation that occurs after a blemish, says Chang. Bhanusali adds that it's also a good option for those want to avoid or can't tolerate hydroquinone, one of the most often used skin-lightening ingredients.
frequency: This depends on what other ingredients it's compounded with and the concentration, but generally it can be used daily.
compatible: Studies have shown that kojic acid works well with and enhances the effects of glycolic acid and hydroquinone, says Nazarian.
incompatible: While it does have a synergetic effect when used with these other brightening/exfoliating ingredients, pairing it with these also increases the likelihood of experiencing excessive dryness or irritation. Proceed with caution and start using any products that contain kojic acid and other actives gradually, giving your skin some time to acclimate.

name: Lactic Acid
benefits: Firmer, thicker skin, resulting in fewer fine lines, wrinkles, and acne lesions.
target: In general, anyone with acne-prone skin or who frequently breaks out.
frequency: It's only recommended for use once a day at maximum, but should probably be used once every few days.
compatible: Hydrating ingredients like hyaluronic acid.
incompatible: Other acids and exfoliants like AHAs or benzoyl peroxide. Retinol should be avoided as well.

name: Lanolin
benefits: Locks moisture into the skin, extremely rejuvenating and healing, allows the skin the moisturize itself from within.
target: In general, those with dry or damaged skin would benefit most from using lanolin products.
frequency: Lanolin products can be used daily, both morning and night.
compatible: Lanolin works best alongside other moisturizing products, as it assists in locking moisture into the skin.
incompatible: In general, lanolin is safe to use with most ingredients and products.

name: Lavender Oil
benefits: Soothes skin, improves acne, protects against free radicals, and combats bacterial and fungal disorders.
target: In general, anyone with acne-prone skin who does not have a contact allergy to lavender or fragrance and does not have sensitive skin.
frequency: Provided you do not have an allergy to the ingredient, lavender oil is safe to use in your daily routine, and how often it is used depends on the type of product.
compatible: Lavender oil can be diluted in a carrier solution, such as a fatty oil. "When lavender is mixed with coconut, jojoba or grapeseed oil, it has wonderful benefits on the skin," Guanche says.
incompatible: Inform your doctor of any medications you’re taking or products you’re using before trying lavender oil.

name: Licorice Extract
benefits: Inhibits the production of an enzyme needed to produce melanin (pigment) in the skin, helps remove excess melanin, has anti-inflammatory benefits.
target: Anyone looking to reap the spot-fading, skin tone-evening benefits, as well as those looking to soothe irritated skin. Plus, unlike many other similar ingredients, it's a good option for pregnant women looking for a safe way to treat melasma.
frequency: This largely depends on the particular product formulation, but in most cases, once or twice a day, maximum, says Chwalek.
compatible: Because of its main benefits, it's often mixed with other antioxidants and skin brighteners, such as niacinamide and vitamin C.
incompatible: Because it does have the potential to be somewhat irritating, Linkner advises not using it in conjunction with retinol and/or hydroquinone.

name: Lysine
benefits: Builds protein and collagen and brings energy to the body.
target: As an essential amino acid, Talakoub says everyone needs lysine as a part of their nutrition.
frequency: Lysine should be consumed as a part of your daily diet. Those with a lysine deficiency may need to take a daily supplement, but Talakoub stresses that it's better to eat the lysine through a healthy, balanced diet than it is to take artificial supplements.
compatible: Other amino acids. "Taking one amino acid isn’t going to help build collagen or proteins in the body," Talakoub says. "But taking all the amino acids together will help build more of the proteins in your body."
incompatible: "Lysine does increase the transportation of calcium in the body, and most people that have normal metabolisms can tolerate it, and most people actually need some calcium in their body," Talakoub explains. "However, if you’re taking a calcium supplement, you probably shouldn’t be taking lysine together with it."

name: Magnesium
benefits: When used in skincare, magnesium reduces acne, calms sensitive skin and rosacea, and improves the skin's overall appearance.
target: In general, all skin types can benefit from magnesium usage. However, those with oily, acne-prone skin will most likely benefit the most.
frequency: Topically, magnesium products can be used daily, preferably at night. If ingested, be careful not to exceed 320mg daily.
compatible: Vitamin C
incompatible: Magnesium absorption-inhibitors, such as high doses of zinc and phosphates. Stress can also cause a magnesium deficiency.

name: Malic Acid
benefits: Exfoliates dead cells on the outermost layer of the skin and promotes cell turnover, leaving skin brighter and more even, and also helping to keep pores unclogged.
target: Anyone looking to fade discoloration and/or achieve more radiant skin, as well as those who are acne-prone. It’s also a good choice for those with sensitive skin and for whom other acids may be too irritating.
frequency: Malic acid can be used once or twice daily, depending on what other ingredients it’s combined with.
compatible: Other alpha-, as well as beta-hydroxy acids at lower doses for synergistic effects, as well as hydrating ingredients such as glycerin and hyaluronic acid. Palep also likes pairing with vitamin C to boost the brightening benefits.
incompatible: Be cautious when using it with other acids, or notoriously harsh or irritating ingredients such as retinoids.

name: Mandelic Acid
benefits: Increase in cell turnover, anti-acne, anti-aging.
target: In general, people with sensitive or acneic skin who want an exfoliant that's less harsh than traditional AHAs.
frequency: Once a week, because over-exfoliating causes irritation and other potential skin conditions.
compatible: Hyaluronic acid, other hydrators.
incompatible: Other AHAs, other peels, retinol, retinoids.

name: Manuka Honey
type: Antibacterial/anti-viral/anti-fungal, as well as an anti-inflammatory and humectant
benefits: Aids in wound healing due to its antibacterial and anti-inflammatory properties; draws in moisture to the skin, and can soothe irritated skin conditions such as eczema and psoriasis.
target: Anyone looking for hydrating and soothing benefits; manuka honey may also be beneficial for those with eczema and acne, notes Chang.
frequency: It can be used once or twice daily.
compatible: Manuka honey works synergistically with other antibiotic ingredients, as well other wound-healing ingredients. It also works well when combined with other hydrating ingredients—such as shea butter and glycerin—to moisturize the skin, says Chang.
incompatible: There are no specific ingredients known to have a negative interaction with manuka honey at the moment, though Linkner cautions that, to be safe, it's best to not pair it with potent active ingredients (think retinoids or acids).

name: Marshmallow Root Extract
benefits: Soothes redness, relieves inflammation, and helps retain moisture.
target: In general, people with sensitive and easily irritated skin.
frequency: Twice a day.
compatible: Products that may otherwise cause irritation.
incompatible: If you're diabetic, don't take it as a supplement because it can lower blood sugar.

name: Marula Oil
benefits: Seals-in hydration and softens skin, offers antioxidant protection, has anti-inflammatory effects, has some antibacterial properties.
target: Marula oil is good for all skin types, says Haley, though, as with most oils, it's especially choice for those with very dry or cracked skin.
frequency: Marula oil can be used daily.
compatible: There aren't any known ingredients that it should be used with, though Rabach points out it can be layered over products with active ingredients (retinoids, peptides, antioxidants) to help seal them into skin and boost their efficacy.
incompatible: There are currently no known ingredients that will interact negatively with marula oil, although you can always have too much of a good thing. Avoid using any other oils in your routine to maintain balanced skin.

name: Methylparaben
benefits: Prevents fungus growth, preserves ingredients, creates antibacterial formulas.
target: It is recommended for all skin types except sensitive, allergic, and/or eczematous skin.
frequency: Methylparaben is found in many daytime and nighttime products. As such, it can be used multiple times per day.
compatible: Since methylparaben lengthens the 'shelf-life' of ingredients, dermatologists say that it works well with all ingredients.
incompatible: Methylparaben is generally safe to use with all ingredients thanks to it's preserving nature.

name: Mineral Oil
benefits: Locks moisture into the skin, softens skin, and improves skin barrier function.
target: "I recommend mineral oil for those with dry, sensitive skin, and it can even be used in those with conditions such as eczema or psoriasis," says Chang. She notes that not only is it a good moisturizing ingredient, but it also has a very low risk of allergic reactions or irritation. Mineral oil products aren't recommended for acne-prone skin.
frequency: This depends largely on the specific product you're using and how dry your skin is, but generally speaking, it's fine to use once or twice daily.
compatible: Humectant ingredients such as glycerin or hyaluronic acid, which attract moisture to the skin, that the mineral oil can then lock in.
incompatible: Because it is very occlusive, don't use it with pore-clogging ingredients, says Nussbaum, particularly if you start to notice blackheads and white heads. (More on whether or not in and of itself can clog your pores in a minute.)

name: Moringa Oil
benefits: Reduces fine lines and wrinkles, improves the overall appearance of the skin, soothes inflammation.﻿﻿
target: In general, all skin types can benefit from using moringa oil.
frequency: Usage varies depending on the specific product, but in general, moringa oil can be used daily, both AM and PM.
compatible: Moringa oil works well with most ingredients.
incompatible: Moringa oil can be used with most ingredients.

name: Muslin Cloths
benefits: Gently exfoliates, deeply cleanses, and reduces inflammation
target: It is recommended for people of all ages and skin types, especially those with easily irritated, overly sensitized skin.
frequency: It can be used daily, morning and night, so long as it's used with light pressure.
compatible: Gel, oil, and balm cleansers
incompatible: Exfoliating scrubs

name: Vitamin B3 (Niacinamide)
benefits: Brightening, prevents signs of aging, reduces acne
target: In general, anyone who wants their skin to be bright or prevent aging.
frequency: You can use it in both morning and evening
compatible: "When using vitamin B3, it is good to combine it with other stable and powerful antioxidants, such as Camellia Sinensis (Green Tea) Catechins, Quercetin and Tocopherol," says Dr. Mun. It also eases irritation related to retinol.
incompatible: N/A, it works well with everything.

name: Octinoxate
benefits: Prevents sunburn, decreases the risk of skin cancer, doesn't leave a white cast.
target: Anyone over the age of six months looking for a chemical sunscreen to protect their skin from UVB rays, particularly if they do not like the consistency of physical mineral sunscreens.
frequency: In general, it's safe to use on a daily basis.
compatible: In order to get broad-spectrum protection, octinoxate will often be combined with avobenzone (a chemical UVA filter). To help stabilize the avobenzone, it typically will come with another filter, octocrylene.
incompatible: Chemical peel ingredients like glycolic acid, as well as any ingredients with a significantly lower pH

name: Panthenol
benefits: Binds to and holds water in the skin, moisturizing and leaving it soft, smooth, and more supple. It also has anti-inflammatory properties and is involved in activating the proliferation of cells that are important for wound healing and restoring the function of the skin barrier.
target: In general, panthenol is good for all skin types, and particularly those with dry or flaky skin.
frequency: Humectants like hyaluronic acid and glycerin, as well as ceramides

name: Polyhydroxy Acid (PHA)
benefits: Repairs skin, exfoliates away dead skin, reduces the appearance of skin damage.
target: PHAs are usually safe for all skin types, but especially for those with oily or acne-prone skin.
frequency: To start, try using PHAs three times a week. You can use it in the form of a toner, a face wash, or even a serum.
compatible: Other acids in low concentrations.
incompatible: Other acids in very high concentrations, retinoids if you're particularly sensitive.

name: Phenoxyethanol
benefits: Prevents the growth of bacteria, enhances shelf life, and stabilizes products.
target: In general, anyone without an allergy. Phenoxyethanol is not recommended for those with sensitive skin or eczema.
frequency: Daily.
compatible: Other preservatives.
incompatible: Phenoxyethanol works well with most, if not all, ingredients.

name: Phytosphingosine
benefits: Skin barrier support, anti-inflammatory, anti-bacterial
target: Almost anyone can benefit
frequency: Daily
compatible: Ceramides, peptides

name: Polypeptides
benefits: Smoothes fine lines, increases collagen production, decreases the appearance of pores.﻿﻿
target: Generally, polypeptides are safe for all skin types.
frequency: For maximum effectiveness, polypeptides should be applied during both morning and nighttime skincare routines.
compatible: Getting a facial peel before applying peptide products will help peptides penetrate the skin more deeply.﻿﻿
incompatible: AHAs will reduce the efficiency of peptides.

name: Pomegranate
benefits: Helps skin regenerate, detoxes the skin, protects against UV radiation
target: In general, people with oily or congested skin will find pomegranate the most beneficial
frequency: Once a day
compatible: Ceramides
incompatible: Works with everything

name: Prickly Pear Oil
benefits: Anti-inflammatory, barrier-boosting, hydrating
target: In general, anyone with sensitive skin in need of hydration, or with hyperpigmentation issues.
frequency: Twice a day.
compatible: Retinols or Vitamin C, which might otherwise irritate the face.

name: Propanediol
benefits: Dissolves ingredients, decreases viscosity, and retains moisture.
target: Generally, anyone looking for an alternative to propylene glycol in their skincare.
frequency: Propanediol is a safe ingredient to use regularly, provided that you do not have a sensitivity to it.
compatible: Because of its wide range of uses, propanediol does not function especially well with any ingredient in particular.
incompatible: According to dermatologists, ropanediol works well with most, if not all, ingredients.

name: Propylene Glycol
benefits: Attracts water and locks it into the skin.
target: In general, anyone who is looking for extra hydration and smoothness of the skin.
frequency: Propylene glycol is a safe ingredient to use regularly, provided that you do not have an allergy to it.
compatible: Because it has so many functions, there isn’t a specific list of ingredients that it works well with.
incompatible: Propylene glycol works well with most, if not all, ingredients.﻿﻿

name: Pycnogenol
benefits: Prevents wrinkles, increases hydration, reduces age spots
target: In general, people with concerns about aging.
frequency: Once a day
compatible: Anti-aging skincare products
incompatible: Diabetics and people on immunosuppressants like prednisone should avoid it due to negative drug interactions.﻿﻿

name: Resveratrol
benefits: Fights aging, protects the skin, and improves the overall appearance of skin.
target: Green says that, in general, anyone who has sun damage can use resveratrol, regardless of their skin type.
frequency: According to Green, it's safe to use on a daily basis as long as you know how your skin responds to the antioxidant.
compatible: Most other powerful antioxidants, like ferulic acid.
incompatible: Neither dermatologist is aware of any ingredient that will deactivate the function of resveratrol.

name: Retin-A
benefits: Increases cell turnover, antioxidant.
target: In general, anyone who wants to prevent bad acne or wrinkles.
frequency: Once a day, maximum. Any more and you're risking serious irritation.
compatible: Hydrators, antioxidants.
incompatible: Vitamin C, physical and chemical exfoliants, other retinol formulas.

name: Retinaldehyde
benefits: Promotes skin cell turnover, improves skin tone, helps unclog pores, thickens the dermis to slow down the formation of wrinkles.
target: Anyone looking for the anti-aging effects of a retinoid, especially those who have used and can tolerate retinol or retinyl palmitate, but aren't seeing the results they want. In this case, you can up the ante to retinaldehyde, which can be more potent and effective at jumpstarting your skin cells, says Nussbaum.
frequency: While it’s important to ease into things in order to let your skin gradually acclimate to the ingredient, it can ultimately be used daily.
compatible: Alpha- and beta-hydroxy acids have commonly been used with retinoids to help further increase skin cell turnover, says Chilukuri (though it's important to make those separate parts of your routine, using one in the AM and one in the PM). Using antioxidants such as vitamin C, vitamin E, and niacinamide can also help improve the skin brightening effects, he adds. However, use these ingredients together with caution, and decrease use if you notice irritation.
incompatible: Avoid using any retinoid at the same time as products with vitamin C, AHAs, or BHAs, as this can up the likelihood of sensitivity and irritation, says Nussbaum. She recommends using the former in the morning (under SPF, of course) and reserving the retinoid for nighttime use.

name: Retinol
benefits: Reduces wrinkles, exfoliates, prevents aging.
target: In general, people with acne or people who are concerned about the appearance of aging skin. It's not recommended for people with sensitive skin due to its ability to irritate the skin.
frequency: Once a day maximum, typically once every few days.
compatible: Anything hydrating, to offset the irritation.
incompatible: Vitamin C; other exfoliants like glycolic acid, and alpha hydroxy acid (AHA); and astringents, as doing so may irritate the skin.

name: Palmitate
benefits: Promotes skin cell turnover, improves skin tone, helps unclog pores, helps thicken the dermis to slow down the formation of wrinkles.
target: Because retinyl palmitate is the least irritating of all four retinoids (more on that in a minute), it's a great option for almost all skin types and anyone who want to keep their pores clear and skin youthful, says Solomon. It does still have to the potential to be somewhat irritating for those with extremely sensitive skin, however.
frequency: While it’s important to ease into things in order to let your skin gradually acclimate to the ingredient, it can ultimately be used daily.
compatible: According to Lain, "Retinoids have a synergistic effect with antioxidants such as vitamins C, E, and ferulic acid." Pairing any retinoid with a sunscreen is also important, since they can make your skin more susceptible to the sun.
incompatible: Since retinyl palmitate has exfoliating properties, avoid combining it with other chemical exfoliants, such as glycolic or salicylic acid, as well as harsh scrubs with abrasive ingredients, cautions Lain. This holds especially true if you fall into the super sensitive skin camp. It can also cause some dryness, notes Solomon, so it's a good idea to pass on toners and astringents, too.

name: Rosehip Oil
benefits: Brightens and evens out the skin, regenerates and heals, helps with anti-aging, elasticity, and collagen production.
target: In general, rosehip oil is beneficial for all skin types.
frequency: It's safe to use twice a day, morning and night.
compatible: In general, rosehip oil can be used with most products and ingredients.
incompatible: Rosehip oil is high in vitamin A, so be mindful when using products with retinoids.

name: Seaweed
benefits: Regulates oil production, exfoliates, brightens, and moisturizes dry, dull skin.
target: Anyone looking for hydrating and exfoliating benefits. Also, those with acne, rosacea, and skin sensitivities will benefit from its healing properties.
frequency: Seaweed extract can be used at any time.
compatible: Seaweed extract is compatible with many ingredients, although it can be used alone. These include Vitamin B3, hyaluronic acid, peptides, and botanical extracts.
incompatible: There are no specific ingredients known to have a negative interaction with seaweed, but Sarfati notes it's always best to work with your skincare professional or esthetician when creating a full skincare program.

name: Shea Butter
benefits: Hydrating, antioxidant, soothes irritation
target: In general, anyone with dry skin
frequency: As much as you want, if you don't have an allergy.
compatible: Other oils, cocoa butter

name: Snail mucin
benefits: Moisturizes skin, promotes collagen production, aids in skin healing and regeneration.
target: In general, snail mucin can be used on all skin types, though its hydrating properties make it especially choice for those with dry skin, says Levin. And unless you’re actually allergic to the ingredient, it’s generally well-tolerated by most. (Though keep in mind that since it is derived from an animal vegans should take a pass.)
frequency: This largely depends on why you're using it—since it does have many benefits—and what type of product it's found in. Generally speaking, you can use snail mucin once or twice per day.
compatible: It’s often combined with antioxidants and retinol, as well as common skincare staples such as vitamin C, glycolic acid, and other moisturizing ingredients.
incompatible: Because research is still limited, it's unknown whether or not it interacts poorly with any other ingredients, says Lain. Right now, there's no evidence that it does.

name: Sodium Ascorbyl Phosphate
benefits: Neutralizes skin-damaging free radicals, boosts collagen production, evens skin tone, has antimicrobial benefits.
target: In general, because this is less potent than other forms of vitamin C, it’s generally safe for all skin types, though some people may experience mild irritation.
frequency: Once to twice daily, although it’s always a good idea to start by using it just a few times per week and gradually increasing the frequency in order to ensure your skin can tolerate it, advises Farber.
compatible: Other antioxidants, in particular vitamin E and ferulic acid, as well as hydrating ingredients such as hyaluronic acid.
incompatible: Benzoyl peroxide can oxidize vitamin C, and retinols work best at a different pH, says Farber. If both of these are a part of your regimen, use them at different times of the day.

name: Sodium Deoxycholate
benefits: Breaks apart fat.
target: In theory, someone who was interested in toning their face might consider trying a product containing sodium deoxycholate. However, the topical benefits are still unclear.
frequency: Because a lot of information is still unknown, it's best to follow the manufacturer's instructions for application.
compatible: Given all the unknowns, Fu and Lu would recommend that if you do want to test sodium deoxycholate out, a great insurance policy would be to add other classic anti-aging ingredients into the mix, like peptides.
incompatible: Lu explains that since penetration seems to be key when dealing with sodium deoxycholate, it would be best to be on the lookout for high amounts of penetration enhancers, which are ingredients such as propylene glycol, ethoxydiglycol, and butylene glycol. These ingredients work by helping the active ingredients in a product penetrate through the skin and make them more effective, but Lu points out that this process can be irritating for those with sensitive and dry skin types.

name: Sodium Hyaluronate
benefits: Improves dryness, Replenishes the skin, and Provides structure and volume.
target: It is recommended for people of all ages and skin types and is especially beneficial for those with dry, dehydrated skin.
frequency: Sodium hyaluronate is safe to use in concentrations of up to 2% twice daily, morning and night.
compatible: Moisturizers.
incompatible: Generally, sodium hyaluronate is safe to use with most, if not all, ingredients.

name: Sodium Lauryl Sulfate
benefits: Creates a lather, Encourages a deep clean, and Emulsifies.
target: Those who don't have an allergy or sensitivity to it.
frequency: Can be used every day if you only apply it to areas that harbor bacteria and limit the amount of time on your skin.
compatible: Moisturizers to counteract the dryness from sodium lauryl sulfate.
incompatible: Physical and chemical exfoliants, as doing so may further irritate the skin.

name: Spironolactone
benefits: Regulates oil production, blocks androgen receptors, and reduces the length of hormonal breakouts.
target: In general, women with hormonal acne or women who have been resistant to other acne treatments in the past. It is not recommended for men or for women who are looking to become pregnant.
frequency: How much you should use it? Consult a dermatologist.
compatible: Generally, it works well with all topical treatments.
incompatible: Check for interactions with other medications.

name: Sulfur
benefits: Kills bacteria, reduces sebum, and sloughs away dead skin.
target: Sulfur can be used to treat those with mild-to-moderate acne, rosacea, seborrheic dermatitis, psoriasis, and eczema.
frequency: According to Shah, it can be used on a daily basis, and some skin types can tolerate some formulations (such as a wash) even twice a day.
compatible: Sodium sulfacetamide. "There are newer formulations of topical sulfur lotions that are combined with sodium sulfacetamide, creating a more gentle and less stinky product," Cheung says.
incompatible: Cheung says to avoid combining sulfur with other topicals that dry out the skin or exfoliate (such as retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, and salicylic acid) to prevent the skin from becoming too dry or inflamed.

name: Tamanu Oil
benefits: Moisturization, antioxidant production, and an anti-inflammatory effect. It also stimulates collagen production to promote wound healing and has some antibacterial properties, particularly against the bacteria associated with acne, notes Petrillo.
target: Those with dry skin, as well as those with minor acne and scarring, or people looking for an oil with anti-aging benefits.
frequency: This depends on the particular product you're using, but generally it can be used once or twice per day.
compatible: According to Gonzalez, it's often combined with other popular skincare oils—rosehip, cranberry seed, avocado—when formulated in serums or lotions.
incompatible: There are currently no ingredients known to have a negative interaction with tamanu oil. Gonzalez does note that if you're using a pure version of tamanu oil on you're face, there's simply no need to apply other oils as well.

name: tepezcohuite
benefits: Moisturizes, and could potentially promote burn- and wound-healing.
target: In general, anyone with dry or irritated skin.
frequency: Not enough scientific studies have been conducted to determine appropriate usage.
compatible: Aloe and tea tree oil.
incompatible: Harsh exfoliators such as glycolic acid, and astringents, as doing so may irritate the skin.

name: Tranexamic Acid
benefits: Fades discoloration, brightens skin, reduces the appearance of acne scars.
target: Generally, tranexamic acid is safe for all skin types. Those with super sensitive skin or eczema should do a test on the inside of the wrist before use, just to be safe.
frequency: Ideally, tranexamic acid would be applied twice a day, but some suggest starting with one application per day to see how it reacts with your skin.
compatible: Vitamin C, SPF, hyaluronic acid, retinol.
incompatible: Multiple different acids, stick to only using it with one or two others to avoid dryness.

name: Triethanolamine
benefits: Stabilizes, balances a product's pH, and thickens the formula.
target: In general, anyone who does not have an allergy to it.
frequency: As long as it's delivered from a standard cosmetic product and does not cause irritation, triethanolamine is considered safe to use on a daily basis by both Romanowski and Schultz.
compatible: As a pH adjuster, triethanolamine works particularly well with acidic materials, Romanowski adds.
incompatible: According to reviews by the Cosmetic Ingredient Review Expert Panel, to prevent the formation of possibly carcinogenic nitrosamines, triethanolamine should not be used with N-nitrosating agents in formulations or should not be used in cosmetic products in which N-nitroso compounds can be formed.

benefits: Soothing, detoxifying, exfoliating.
target: In general, people with inflammation, acne scarring, or puffiness.
frequency: At max once a day, lest you start to stain your skin. If you're using kasturi turmeric, as much as you want.
compatible: Honey, apple cider vinegar, gram flour, milk, anything else you use in at-home masks.
incompatible: Lime—the two used together are a common homemade treatment for skin lightening.

name: Undecylenic Acid
benefits: Prevents and eliminates topical fungus
target: Individuals with diagnosed fungal skin infections can benefit from using an anti-fungal topical treatment containing undecylenic acid, says Rabach.
frequency: Most over-the-counter products can be applied twice daily.
compatible: It works well with and is often formulated with zinc. This combination provides a soothing and healing environment for the skin, which can become irritated from a fungal infection, says Greenfield. Rabach adds that combining undecylenic acid with zinc may also help minimize the potentially irritating side effects that the ingredient might cause.
incompatible: According to Rabach, there's no data showing that it's problematic to use it with any other ingredients.

name: Urea 40
benefits: Dissolves the intracellular matrix, which loosens dead, scaly skin. This makes it ideal for treating calluses, dermatitis, psoriasis, eczema, and keratosis pilaris. It also draws moisture into the skin for serious hydration.
target: Anyone with excessively dry, flaky/scaly skin, or who has one of the above skin conditions.
frequency: Generally, you should apply to the affected areas 1 to 3 times a day (or as directed by your physician). Unless the treatment area is on the hands, remember to wash them immediately after using the product so as not to inadvertently treat the skin on the hands.
compatible: Products with Urea 40 should be used alone.

name: Vitamin B3 (Niacinamide)
benefits: Brightening, prevents signs of aging, reduces acne
target: In general, anyone who wants their skin to be bright or prevent aging.
frequency: You can use it in both morning and evening
compatible: "When using vitamin B3, it is good to combine it with other stable and powerful antioxidants, such as Camellia Sinensis (Green Tea) Catechins, Quercetin and Tocopherol," says Dr. Mun. It also eases irritation related to retinol.
incompatible: N/A, it works well with everything.

name: Vitamin C
benefits: Protects against free radical damage, evens skin tone, and promotes collagen production.
target: Vitamin C is not recommended for those with extremely sensitive skin and can be problematic for those with oily skin. Herrmann recommends asking your board-certified dermatologist which brand may be best suited for your skin type.
frequency: Herrmann recommends using vitamin C daily or every other day.
compatible: Vitamin C works well with complementing antioxidants like, vitamin E and ferulic acid, which will boost the efficacy and stability of the molecule.
incompatible: According to Herrmann, avoid it using with benzoyl peroxide, which can oxidize the vitamin C and make it useless very quickly. Also avoid using it with other acids, which may cause excessive skin irritation, especially if used daily. And lastly, don't it use with retinol, which can make the vitamin C more unstable and less likely to penetrate the skin.﻿﻿

name: Vitamin D
benefits: Calms inflammation, protects the skin, and improves cell turnover.
target: Someone who is deficient should take a vitamin D supplement. Those looking to fight inflammatory skin diseases can consider a prescription topical.
frequency: According to the National Institutes of Health, the average, non-deficient adult should aim for 600 International Units (IU) per day in their diet. As far as topically, Zeichner says there is no harm in using a vitamin D cream daily.
compatible: When treating psoriasis, Gerstner says topical vitamin D is often used in conjunction with a topical steroid. If using topical vitamin D for anti-aging, Herrmann recommends combining it with other antioxidant vitamins, growth factors, or retinoids.
incompatible: Zeichner says topical vitamin D cannot be combined with hydroxy acids, like glycolic or salicylic acid, because the acidic pH has been shown to inactivate vitamin D.

name: Vitamin E
benefits: Seals in moisture, smooths skin, antioxidant.
target: In general, anyone with dry skin. Vitamin E is not recommended for sensitive skin.
frequency: You should only use Vitamin E once a day maximum, preferably at night, as it is usually too thick to put under makeup.
compatible: Vitamin C and Ferulic acid.
incompatible: Retinol/Vitamin A.﻿﻿

name: Vitamin F
benefits: Hydrates, replenishes, is high in antioxidants, is anti-inflammatory, restores the skin's barrier.
target: In general, all skin types would benefit from vitamin F usage, but especially those with acneic skin.
frequency: Vitamin F is safe to use twice a day, morning and night.
compatible: Hydrators, linoleic acid, anti-aging products, and SPF products.
incompatible: In general, vitamin F can be used with all ingredients safely.

name: Volcanic Ash
benefits: Clarifying, antibacterial, reduces oxidation.
target: In general, people with acneic, oily skin.
frequency: Try not to use it more than once every few days, as it can be drying.
compatible: Hydrating ingredients like hyaluronic acid.
incompatible: Not recommended for use with other exfoliants, as it can be stripping.

name: zinc
benefits: Anti-inflammatory, anti-bacterial, regulates oil
target: In general, people with acneic skin.
frequency: You should only take it once a day, 40mg max.
compatible: Multivitamins, other sources of zinc that might overload you.﻿﻿
